## **Previously on 201**
<br>
.pull-left[<br><img src="../pic/1121/english.jpg" width="90%">]
.pull-right[
**vowel articulation**
- tongue <span style="color:green"><b>height</b></span> (high, mid, low)
- tongue <span style="color:green"><b>backness</b></span> (front, central, back)
- lip <span style="color:green"><b>roundness</b></span> (rounded, unrounded)
- <span style="color:orange"><b>nasalisation</b></span>
- <span style="color:orange"><b>vowel length</b></span>
- <span style="color:orange"><b>pitch</b></span> (tone, etc)<br><br>

**categories to differentiate consonants**
- **voicing**
  - <b>whether</b> the vocal cords vibrate or not
- <span style="color:green"><b>place</b></span>
  - <b>where</b> the obstruction of airflow in the vocal tract is
- <span style="color:blue"><b>manner</b></span>
  - <b>what type</b> of obstruction of airflow occurs
]

---
.pull-left[
## **Some Terms**
<br>
**Phonetics**: study of speech sounds as a physical phenomenon<br><br>
**Phonology**: study of how languages organize speech sounds into a **system** (pattern)<br><br>
**phoneme**: a set of sounds that speakers of a language treat as being the same
- writen in a pair of slahses: <span style="color:green"><b>/b/</b></span>, <span style="color:green"><b>/d/</b></span>, <span style="color:green"><b>/g/</b></span><br><br>

**allophone**: each individual possible sound that a <span style="color:blue"><b>phoneme</b></span> could surface as<br><br>
**Phonotactics**: <span style="color:green"><b>rules</b></span> for how we combine sounds to form words
- English doesn't allow the velar nasal (**[ŋ]**) at the beginning of a word, but Shanghainese does
]
.pull-right[
<br>
<div style="text-align:center">
<span style="color:red"><b>/SUPERMAN/</b></span>

<br><br>
<span style="color:red"><b>/HULK/</b></span>
<br><br><img src="../pic/1121/hulk.jpeg" width="70%">
</div>
]

## **Contrastive and Complementary Distribution**
.pull-left[
<br><br>
**contrastive distribution**: when switching out one phoneme for another results in a different meaning
- these word pairs are called <span style="color:green"><b>minimal pairs</b></span>
- they detect which sounds are <span style="color:blue"><b>phonemes</b></span>
- [**ð**æt] ('*that*') vs. [**m**æt] ('*mat*')<br><br>

**complementary distribution**: when switching a sound out for another sound does not change the meaning
- these sounds are allophones of the **same** phoneme
- different environments cause the sound to <span style="color:green"><b>change</b></span>, but in the minds of speakers they are still considered <span style="color:blue"><b>one</b></span> sound
- [**p**ejs] ('*pace*') vs. [s**p<sup>h</sup>**ejs] ('*space*')
]
.pull-right[
<br>
<div style="text-align:center">
<span style="color:blue"><b>/p/</b></span><br><br>
<span style="color:red"><b>/SUPERMAN/</b></span>
<br><br><img src="../pic/1121/superman.png" width="75%">
</div>
<br>
.pull-left[
<div style="text-align:center">
<span style="color:green">[<i>Clark Kent</i>]</span><br><br>
<span style="color:blue">[<i>p</i>]</span> in <span style="color:orange">[s</span><span style="color:blue">p</span><span style="color:orange">ejs]</span>
</div>
]
.pull-right[
<div style="text-align:center">
<span style="color:green">[<i>superman</i>]</span><br><br>
<span style="color:blue">[<i>p<sup>h</sup></i>]</span> in <span style="color:blue">[p<sup>h</sup></span><span style="color:orange">ejs]</span>
</div>
]
]

## **"Common" Sounds**
<br>
.pull-left[<br><br><img src="../pic/1121/dog.png" width="90%">]
.pull-right[
Different languages **contrast** different sounds, but, there are some **common trends**
<br><br>
<div style="text-align:center">
<table style="width:70%; border-collapse: collapse; margin:auto; font-size:20px;">
  <tr>
    <th style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:10px; text-align:center;"><span style="color:blue"><b>more common</b></span></th>
    <th style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:10px; text-align:center;"><span style="color:green"><b>less common</b></span></th>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:20px; text-align:center; vertical-align:top;">
      [a]<br>
      [k] *or* [s]<br>
      [t]<br>
      [p, t, k]<br>
      [d] *or* [z]<br>
      [k]<br>
    </td>
    <td style="border: 1px solid #555; padding:20px; text-align:center; vertical-align:top;">
      [ǎ] (nasalised)<br>
      [x]<br>
      [s]<br>
      [b, d, g]<br>
      [ð]<br>
      [q]<br>
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
</div>
<br>
If a language has the sounds on the <span style="color:green"><b>right</b></span> of each row, then it will also have the corresponding sound on the <span style="color:blue"><b>left</b></span>
]

## **<i>Phoneme</i> or <i>Allophone</i>?**
<br>
.pull-left[
**[step 1]** for each word, write the <span style="color:green"><b>preceding</b></span> and <span style="color:blue"><b>following</b></span> segment for **the sound** you're testing<br><br>
**[step 2]** write down each different environment (again, looking at both the <span style="color:green"><b>preceding</b></span> and <span style="color:blue"><b>following</b></span> sounds)<br><br>
**[step 3]** see if there are any **common environments** that both potential phonemes share<br><br>
<span style="color:orange"><b>notes</b></span>
- **minimal pairs** are used to find evidence that two sounds are **phonemes**
- **\#**: word boundary, **_**: the sound being tested<br><br>
[<span style="color:green"><b>\#</b></span>\_<span style="color:blue"><b>æ</b></span>t] ('*that*') **&** [<span style="color:green"><b>\#</b></span>\_<span style="color:blue"><b>æ</b></span>t] ('*mat*') -- **phoneme**<br><br> 
[<span style="color:green"><b>\#</b></span>\_<span style="color:blue"><b>ej</b></span>s] ('*pace*') **&** 
[<span style="color:green"><b>s</b></span>\_<span style="color:blue"><b>ej</b></span>s] ('*space*') -- **allophone**
]
.pull-right[
<br><img src="../pic/1121/horse.jpg" width="80%">
]

## **Practice: Sindhi**
<br>
Examine the distribution of the sounds **[p]**, **[p<sup>h</sup>]**, **[b]** in these words from <span style="color:green"><b>Sindhi</b></span>, an Indo-European language spoken in Pakistan and India. Do you notice any **minimal pairs**? <br><br>
If so, what does that mean for these sounds – are they in **contrastive** or **complementary** distribution? Are they separate **phonemes** or are they **allophones** of the same phoneme?<br><br>
.pull-left[
1. [pənu] 'leaf' <br><br>
2. [vədʒu] 'opportunity' <br><br>
3. [ʃeki] 'suspicious' <br><br>
4. [gədo] 'dull' <br><br>
5. [dəru] 'door' <br><br>
6. [p<sup>h</sup>ənu] 'hood of snake'
]
.pull-right[
<ol start="7">
  <li>[təru] 'bottom'</li> <br>
  <li>[k<sup>h</sup>əto] 'sour'</li> <br>
  <li>[bədʒu] 'run'</li> <br>
  <li>[bənu] 'forest'</li> <br>
  <li>[bətʃu] 'be safe'</li> <br>
  <li>[dʒədʒu] 'judge'</li>
</ol>
]

## **Practice: Quechua**
<br>
Examine the sounds <span style="color:orange"><b>[u]</b></span> and <span style="color:blue"><b>[o]</b></span> in this data from **Quechua**. Write down **all** of the environments in which each sound occurs. Do you notice any patterns?<br>
Does the pattern suggest the sounds are in **contrastive** or **complementary** distribution? Are they separate <span style="color:deeppink"><b>phonemes</b></span> or <span style="color:deeppink"><b>allophones</b></span> of the same phoneme?
<br><br>
.pull-left[
.pull-left[
1. [k<span style="color:orange"><b>u</b></span>sa] 'nice'<br><br>
2. [q<span style="color:blue"><b>o</b></span>mer] 'green'<br><br>
3. [tiŋk<span style="color:orange"><b>u</b></span>] 'meeting'<br><br>
4. [p<span style="color:orange"><b>u</b></span>ka] 'red'<br><br>
5. [q<span style="color:blue"><b>o</b></span>sa] 'husband'
]
.pull-right[
<ol start="6">
  <li>[p<span style="color:orange"><b>u</b></span>ŋk<span style="color:orange"><b>u</b></span>] 'door'</li> <br>
  <li>[aʎq<span style="color:blue"><b>o</b></span>] 'dog'</li> <br>
  <li>[s<span style="color:orange"><b>u</b></span>wa] 'thief'</li> <br>
  <li>[q<span style="color:blue"><b>o</b></span>sq<span style="color:blue"><b>o</b></span>] 'Cusco'</li> <br>
  <li>[q<span style="color:blue"><b>o</b></span>tʃa] 'lake'</li> <br>
</ol>
]
<br>
